greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: R(n) - p(2n), where R(n) is the n-th Ramanujan prime and p(n) is the n-th prime.
comment: The sequence tends to decrease at runs of Ramanujan primes and at twin Ramanujan primes.
Is 4 the minimum value of a(n) for all n > 1? Is the sequence unbounded? What are its liminf and limsup? Is a(n)/n bounded?
Christian Axler has proved that the answers to the 1st, 2nd, and 4th questions are yes, and that liminf a(n) = limsup a(n) = infinity. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Feb 12 2014
a(n) > n, for 1 < n < 86853959 = limit. For limit, a(n) = 135595760, a(n) - n = 48741801. - _John W. Nicholson_, Dec 19 2013
link: John W. Nicholson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Christian Axler, On generalized Ramanujan primes, arXiv:1401.7179 [math.NT], 2014.
J. Sondow, Ramanujan primes and Bertrand's postulate, Amer. Math. Monthly, 116 (2009), 630-635.
J. Sondow, J. W. Nicholson, and T. D. Noe, Ramanujan Primes: Bounds, Runs, Twins, and Gaps, J. Integer Seq. 14 (2011) Article 11.6.2
formula: a(n) >= 2 for n > 1 (see "Ramanujan primes and Bertrand's postulate").
a(n)/p(2n) = R(n)/p(2n) - 1 -> 0 as n -> infinity (see same link).
mathematica: Do[If[PrimeQ[k], s++]; If[PrimeQ[k/2], s--]; If[s < nn, R[[s + 1]] = k], {k, Prime[3 nn]}];
Table[R[[n]] - Prime[2 n], {n, 1, nn}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 07 2018, using _T. D. Noe_'s code for R *)
xref: a(n) = 2*A233740(n) for n > 1. Records are A233741.
results.author: _Jonathan Sondow_, Dec 15 2013
